title: Why do we need to license?
displayTitle: Why do we need to license?
body:
For data to be open, it should be accessible (this usually means being published online) and licensed for anyone to access, use and share.

In this module we’ll look at:
  • Why open data needs to be licensed
  • How licences unlock the value of open data
  • What type of licence suits open data
  • How to provide for open data licensing in the tender, procurement and contracting lifecycle

title: Simplifying open data licences – in 2 minutes
displayTitle: Simplifying open data licences – in 2 minutes
body: The ODI’s Ellen Broad explains why we need open data licences, how they help unlock the value of data and best practice in choosing the right type of licence.

title: Why license open data?
body:
Without a licence, data is not truly open.

A licence tells anyone that they can access, use and share your data.

For data to be open, it should be accessible (usually available online) and licensed for anyone to access, use and share.

Unless you have a licence, data will be ‘publicly available’, but users may not have permission to access use and share it under copyright or database laws.

title: Unlocking the value in open data
displayTitle: Unlocking the value in open data
body: Licensing gives permission to businesses, startups, governments or other organisations to innovate with open data.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Providing certainty
_items.body:
Open data licences provide users with certainty that the data can be used and shared for a wide range of purposes.

A licence is an explicit permission to use the data for both commercial and non-commercial purposes.

Without a licence, users may find themselves in a legal grey area.

_items.title: Providing clarity
_items.body:
Only 20% (approximately) of open data providers across the European Union are truly open licensed (as of 2015).

In the EU, copyright and database laws are complex. While data might be intended to be open, a licence provides legal clarity for users.

The OpenDataMonitor platform provides information and statistics on European open data catalogues.
Take me to the OpenDataMonitor platform

_graphic.alt: A graph of open licences across countries
_graphic.title: A graph of open licences across countries

_items.title: Enabling innovation
_items.body:
Open data licences enable experimentation, exploration and innovative uses of open data in new products and services.

For example, Transport for London’s transport data is openly licensed. It has underpinned a wide range of public transport journey planners, available as apps on smartphones and mobile devices.
Take me to Transport for London

_graphic.alt: A map from a to b
_graphic.title: A map from a to b

title: How to locate a licence?
body:
Publishers of open data should provide easy access to the licence for all datasets that are available to access, use and share.

The location and format for licence information will vary according to jurisdiction, industry and individual style.

Best practice suggests that licences should be easy to find and read, and in the next section we show you how to find a licence.

title: Simple licences, easily found
body: Every publisher of open data presents their licences differently.  Here are some examples.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: UK Government
_items.body:
The UK Government uses an Open Government Licence.

This example clearly shows the licence at the top of the web page where the dataset is accessed. The licence information is a hyperlink that displays the licence in full.

Have a look at this example dataset and its licence. While you are there, feel free to explore all the other datasets and services they offer.
Take me to Data.gov.uk

_items.title: Singapore Government
_items.body:
Singapore government also publishes open data which is ‘licenced’ or subject to terms and conditions rather than an open or standard licence.

The ‘licence’ terms and conditions are accessed by clicking on the data download icons or URL, or via the terms and conditions link at the very bottom of the web page.

Have a look at this example dataset and its licence. While you are there, feel free to explore all the other datasets and services they offer.
Take me to data.gov.sg

title: Types of licences
body:
The simpler the licence, the better!

There are lots of different licences. To maximise reuse, try to adopt a licence standard that is already widely used.

_items.title: Creative Commons licences
_items.body:
Creative Commons licences are widely used for open content. Version 4.0 explicitly considers data licensing.

There are three Creative Commons versions of an open licence:

  • Public domain: (CC0)
  • Attribution: (CC-BY v4.0)
  • Attribution & share-alike: (CC-BY-SA v4.0)

The public domain and attribution licences give most flexibility in the use of data while a share-alike licence may limit the commercial use of the data.
Show me a Public Domain licence
Show me an Attribution licence
Show me an Attribution & share-alike licence

You can build your own licence at the Creative Commons website –
Show me how to make my own Creative Commons licence

_items.title: Bespoke licences
_items.body:
Bespoke licences can increase the complexity for users of open data.

They may introduce specific conditions that limit usage, restrict data integration and in some cases, are practicably difficult for re-users to comply with.

_items.title: UK Open Government licence
_items.body:
Some publishers have chosen to develop their own licences.

The best examples are:

  • short
  • compatible with widely used licences
  • easy to comply with

The UK Government has a good example of an open licence developed in this way that is used by UK Government departments -
Take me to the UK Government open licence

title: Licences and third parties
body: The publication of open data may be required as part of the tendering, procurement and contracting lifecycle.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Third parties
_items.body:
Governments and organisations engage contractors who provide services on their behalf.

These governments and organisations may be committed to publishing open data, and extend that to third parties.

This is important because where public money is spent, it should add public resource.

_items.title: Including open data in contracts
_items.body:
To ensure that data collected and used by contractors is also published as open data, an organisation can:

  • include this as a condition in the contract
  • retain ownership of the data to publish it as open data themselves

_items.title: Open data about performance
_items.body:
A contractor for services can also require performance data and any data related to the formation of procured services be published as open data.

Past performance data helps potential suppliers understand which parts of the contract are easy or difficult, and enables competition during the tendering process.

title: Are you ready to license?
body: There are four simple things to remember when it comes to licensing. Can you recall them?

title: Why license open data?
body: What is the most important aspect of publishing data that permits users to access, use and share the data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Without a licence, data will be ‘publicly available’, but users may have not have permission to access use and share it under copyright and/or database laws.

_incorrect.notFinal:

title: Unlocking the value in open data
displayTitle: Unlocking the value in open data
body: An open licence allows users to access, use and share open data. What other permission must an open licence provide users?

_items.text: Claim ownership of the open data.
Ability to place blame on provider for financial loss.
Ability to use the open data commercially.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

In order for data to be truly open, users must be free to use the data even for commercial purposes. This maximises the innovation. The licence does not have to provide warranty or allow others to claim ownership of the source data.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

In order for data to be truly open, users must be free to use the data even for commercial purposes. This maximises the innovation. The licence does not have to provide warranty or allow others to claim ownership of the source data.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

In order for data to be truly open, users must be free to use the data even for commercial purposes. This maximises the innovation. The licence does not have to provide warranty or allow others to claim ownership of the source data.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Without a licence, data will be ‘publicly available’, but users may have not have permission to access use and share it under copyright and/or database laws.
_partlyCorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Without a licence, data will be ‘publicly available’, but users may have not have permission to access use and share it under copyright and/or database laws.

title: Types of licences
body: Which of the following type of licence would best suit a UK Government department who wanted to publish open data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

UK Government agencies may be restricted in the use of Creative Commons licensing, so they have developed their own UK Open Government licence

_incorrect.notFinal:

UK Government agencies may be restricted in the use of Creative Commons licensing, so they have developed their own UK Open Government licence.

title: Licences and third parties
body: Do open licences have a place in the tendering, procurement and contracting lifecycle?

_items.text: Only if contractors ask for them.
No, a licence should not be part of the process.
Open licences should be integral to the contract lifecycle.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is core to the procurement lifecycle. Organisations tendering for services can publish performance data and related data to help businesses bid for services.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Open data is core to the procurement lifecycle. Organisations tendering for services can publish performance data and related data to help businesses bid for services.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data is core to the procurement lifecycle. Organisations tendering for services can publish performance data and related data to help businesses bid for services.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

_partlyCorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data is core to the procurement lifecycle. Organisations tendering for services can publish performance data and related data to help businesses bid for services.

title: Open data licences.  Simple.
body:
For your data to be open, it should be accessible (usually published online) and licensed for anyone to access, use and share.

Licensing gives permission to businesses, startups, governments or other organisations to be innovative with your open data.

Open data licensing should be provided for in the tendering, procurement and contracting lifecycle.

And remember, the simpler the licence, the better!

In the next module, we assess open data quality and look at how easy it is to prepare data for users to use and unlock its value.
